Let $k\geq 3$ and $A$ be an additive basis of order $k$. Does there exist a constant $c=c(k)>0$ such that if $r(n)\geq c\log n$ for all large $n$ then $A$ must contain a minimal basis of order $k$? (Here $r(n)$ counts the number of representations of $n$ as the sum of at most $k$ elements from $A$.)



A question of Erd\H{o}s and Nathanson \cite{ErNa79}, who proved that this is true for $k=2$ if $1_A\ast 1_A(n) > (\log \frac{4}{3})^{-1}\log n$ for all large $n$.

Härtter \cite{Ha56} and Nathanson \cite{Na74} proved that there exist additive bases which do not contain any minimal additive bases.

See also [868].




References


[ErNa79] Erd\H{o}s, Paul and Nathanson, Melvyn B., Systems of distinct representatives and minimal bases in
additive number theory. (1979), 89--107.

[Ha56] H\"{a}rtter, Erich, Ein Beitrag zur {T}heorie der {M}inimalbasen. J. Reine Angew. Math. (1956), 170--204.

[Na74] Nathanson, Melvyn B., Minimal bases and maximal nonbases in additive number theory. J. Number Theory (1974), 324--333.
